fields.name: Insulate your water heater
fields.content:
Your hot water heater needs a Snuggie™ — I mean, "insulating blanket" — if it has an R-value of less than 24. Don't know your hot water heater's R-value...or even what an R-value is? Relax. Journey to your basement or utility closet and touch the outside of your water heater. Warm to the touch? That's your money escaping!Ibid.

Fix it with these three easy steps:

Step 1: Size your hot water heater

You'll need to know the gallon size of your hot water tank. Your manual has this information, but if you're like us, your manual is long gone.

No big. Most residential hot water heaters hold 30-50 gallons.Nunan, Jon. "Hot Water Needs" Service Magic. n.d. 20 Jan. 2010 Unless your house is unusually big, you can work with this number.

Step 2: Buy an insulation kit

Armed with the knowledge about your heater's size, head to your local hardware store. While shopping for water heater blankets, you'll come across a happy surprise: insulating blankets are downright cheap. Most sell for under $20. Since they'll save you a bundle on hot water costs, you'll easily recoup your investment in less than a year,Based on calculations from http://www.energystar.gov/index.cfm?c=products.pr_pie and keep saving money for years to come. Okay, let's pick the right blanket and start saving money right away. Buy one that fits your water heater and has an R-value of 8 or more."Energy Savers: Insulate Your Water Heater Tank for Energy Savings." U.S. Department of Energy. 24 March 2009. 3 March 2010. Then head back home and get it installed.

Step 3: Install the insulation

Your time is now! If you have an electric hot water heater, you can easily install the insulation yourself. This video will give you the low-down, but all you need is scissors and a couple of free minutes.
Installing blankets on gas and oil powered heaters is a bit trickier. You want to make sure you keep the insulation away from both the bottom and top of the heater. We recommend having a qualified professional do it for you. Safety first!

{% action_form %}
fields.teaser: Keep your hot water heater warm and toasty with a hot water heater blanket. It's a Snuggie™ for your hot water heater that can save 10% on your water heating costs!"Energy Savers: Insulate Your Water Heater Tank for Energy Savings." U.S. Department of Energy. 24 March 2009. 3 March 2010.

fields.name: Replace your outdated refrigerator
fields.content:
Your refrigerator is the biggest energy-guzzling appliance in your home."Energy Savers Tip: Appliances." Department of Energy. 22 Jan 2009. 30 March 2010. By replacing it with a newer model, you can really cut your energy use. A new refrigerator uses 30-40% less energy than a 10-year-old unit.Statistic for a typical, new 18.5-cu.-ft. refrigerator with top-mount freezer (without a through-the-door ice dispenser). "Residential Sector: Efficient Refrigerators." Flex Your Power. n.d. 30 March 2010. There's nothing shallow about those savings.

Seeing Stars

Look for the blue Energy Star label when selecting your appliance. Energy Star refrigerators use 20% less energy than similar, non-certified models." This calculator will tell you how much more energy you current fridge is wasting when compared to a new model. You can find an Energy Star model for almost any type of refrigerator, giving you access to all the latest features.

{% action_form %}
fields.teaser: Instead of starting a remodel by putting in new tiles, why not start with an investment that will pay you dividends every month?

fields.name: Set your water heater to 120°F
fields.content:
Many manufacturers pre-set their hot water heaters to 140°. Sure — everyone loves a hot bath. But 140° can be especially dangerous for children and senior citizens.

Take five minutes to save $200

Time to take control from the hot water bosses — and save a stack of cash. By moving your hot water heater temperature from 140° to 120°, you'll save around $200 over five years.Vandenbergh, Michael P. et al. "Individual Carbon Emissions: The Low-Hanging Fruit." UCLA Law Review 1701 (2008): 1746 Your owner's manual will include instructions on how to adjust the temperature setting. If your manual is long gone, you'll find it's pretty easy to locate the thermostat. Consult this chart to find the location of your thermostat.

{% action_form %}
fields.teaser: A long time ago, in a secret meeting in a smoke-filled room, hot water bosses got together and decided to pre-set hot water tanks to 140°. Time to take control from the hot water bosses — and save a stack of cash.

fields.name: Have a home energy audit
fields.content:
A home audit will give you the tools to understand and unlock the unique energy saving opportunities in your home.

Step 1: Find an energy auditor

We recommend working with an energy auditor who is participating in the Home Performance with Energy Star program. Home Performance with Energy Star, a program of the Department of Energy, is now available in many states. Many states also offer incentives for both energy audits and the retrofit work. To find out if your state is participating, visit this page. If your state is not a participating member, you can still receive high-quality work from auditors who have standards like BPI and RESNET. Visit the BPI and RESNET page to find an auditor near you:
  • Find a BPI auditor
  • Find a RESENT auditor

Step 2: Organize your documents

Think of any concerns you may already have and collect your recent utility bills.

Step 3: Have the audit

Your auditor will perform several tests to measure your home's overall leakiness and pinpoint problems. At the end of the audit, your auditor will present you with a list of recommendations that solve your home's specific problems.

Remember...

The audit is just the first step. With your auditor's recommendations in hand, you can work with a contractor to make the right improvements to your home.

{% action_form %}
fields.teaser: Home energy auditors help you find solutions to the unique problems in your home.

fields.name: Insulate your hot water pipes
fields.content:
If you insulate your pipes, they can deliver water that's 2–4ºF hotter — allowing you to turn your water heater down.Department of Energy, Energy Savers, Insulate Hot Water Pipes for Energy Saving Insulating your pipes is a fast, easy activity for a rainy Sunday afternoon.

Step 1: Buy the insulation

You can get the insulation everywhere and it's cheap. Measure the diameter of your pipes before you head to the store, or ask a store clerk about the most common sizes. The diameter of your pipe should match the diameter of the insulation sleeve for a snug fit.

Step 2: Install the insulation

Installing the insulation is one of the easiest ways you can save energy: cut, wrap, and tape. The most important pipes are the ones that are three feet or closer to your hot water heater."Water Heaters - Energy Choices at Home." California Energy Commission. n.d. 5 March 2010. If you have a gas or oil-powered water heater, make sure to keep your insulation at least six inches away from the flue.Mighigan Dept. of Energy, Labor & Economic Growth, The Energy Observer "Increasing Your Water Heater's Efficiency." December 2008. 5 March 2010. Watch this video to see how simple it can be!

{% action_form %}
fields.teaser: As water travels through your pipes, it loses energy to the surrounding air. Instead of warming up your basement, keep that energy where it belongs with pipe insulation.

fields.name: Install a chimney draft guard
fields.content:
Drafts are always trying to weasel their way into your home, and fireplaces are their accomplices. Instead of keeping you warm, unused fireplaces are are a huge source of drafts. Drafts come charging down the flue, pulling warm air away from your hearth and letting cold air come right on in to your family room. In fact, fireplaces account for 14% of total "air infiltration" in the typical home."Energy Savers Booklet: Tips on Saving Energy & Money at Home." Department of Energy. May 2009. 29 March 2010. Brrr!

Stop drafts in their tracks by using a chimney draft guard whenever your fireplace is not in use. Only you can prevent leaky fireplaces. Check out how easy they are to install and use:

Step 1: Size your fireplace

It's important that the chimney draft guard fits snugly.

Step 2: Order your draft guard

Step 3: Install the draft guard

Keep the guard in place whenever you're not using your fireplace — unless you need to leave it open for Santa or other visitors unaccustomed to using doors. When the guard comes in contact with heat, it will deflate and fall out, so there's no risk of combustion.

{% action_form %}
fields.teaser: It looks like a balloon, but it's actually an incredibly effective stopper for your chimney.

fields.name: Use the cold wash cycle
fields.content:
Imagine if your washing machine could talk. What would it say?

  • "Stop spilling mustard on your shirts!"
  • "Switch to the cold cycle!"
Whoa, that was a little scary, huh? Still — you might want to listen. When you wash your clothes in hot water, 90% of the energy is used to heat the water.Chua, Jasmin M. "Beat the Heat, Wash in Cold." Planet Green. 23 March 2008. 3 March 2010. By switching to the cold cycle, you save energy and money. Your clothes will be brighter and your wallet will be mightier!

"But wait, will my clothes still get clean?"

Absolutely. There are many laundry detergents available that are specifically formulated to work with cold water, including Tide Coldwash™ and Woolite Liquid Cold Water Wash™. Unless you're dealing with stains that are unusually greasy, cold water will do the job.

{% action_form %}
fields.teaser: Every time you wash your clothes, you could be saving 90% on energy costs by switching to the cold cycle.

fields.name: Eliminate vampire power
fields.content:
How you can become a vampire slayer

Vampire electronics are lurking in your home! Use the form below to identify your home's energy vampires and make a plan for slaying them. After you're done, you can rest assured that you have a vampire-free home.

{% include "actions/vampire_power/_vampire_worksheet_forms.html" %}

What is vampire power?

Have you seen a glowing light on your DVD player?
What about a blinking button on your TV?

While seemingly innocent, all of these are sure signs that there are vampires in your home — energy vampires. 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, these vampires are stealing energy right out from under your nose!

Almost all of your electronics are energy vampires, and they drink up a lot of energy. On average, 75% of the total energy used by electronics is consumed when they're switched "off."Department of Energy, Appliances & Electronics Every year, these vampires suck away more than $3 billion from American households."Pulling the plug on standby power." The Economist. 10 March 2006.

Why do electronics use so much energy when they're off?

In short, your electronics are not really "off." Let's take your DVD player as an example. Obviously, when it's on, your DVD player uses energy to play your movies and CDs. But when it's "off," your DVD player still needs energy to power its infrared sensor, which is waiting for a signal from your remote. Your DVD player isn't too smart. It doesn't know that it's 3am and you're not going to be watching season four of "The Sopranos" any time soon. So it waits, using energy the whole time. Many DVD players also use energy to power clocks and lights when they're "off."

Adding up the costs

When it's playing a movie, the average DVD player uses around 15 Watts. But when it's "off," it uses around 5 Watts to power all those other features."Standby Power: Data." Lawrence Berkley National Laboratory. n.d. 26 April 2010. Let's say you use you DVD player for one hour every day, and it's "off" for the remaining 23 hours. How much energy is used during each time?

15 Watts x 1 hour = 15 Watt-hours of energy
5 Watts x 23 hours = 115 Watt-hours of energy

Eeek! Over 80% of the energy used by the average DVD player is consumed when it's turn off! That's even above the average of 75% for electronics. If you have an energy monitor, you can play energy detective and find the percentage for each electronic in your home. But one thing is clear — it's time to get rid of energy vampires now!

Learn more: conventional power strips
Vampires often hang out together. Your television, DVD player, cable box, and video game system may all be plugged into the same power strip. When you’re done watching television, turn off the button on your power strip. You can slay all the vampires on the strip with just a flick of a switch.

Remember, your electronics will still be protected from “surges” when the power strip is turned off.

Learn more: smart power strips
Looking for a power strip that takes some initiative? Meet the smart power strip. Smart power strips know when it’s time to cut power to an outlet. There are many different versions of smart power strips available. The BITS power strip senses when you’ve turned off your television or computer, and automatically powers down the other outlets. The Belkin power strip turns off automatically after 11 hours, unless you press a button to keep it on.

Smart power strips also have “always on” outlets. You guessed it: these outlets stay on all the time, even when other outlets have powered down.

fields.name: Use a programmable thermostat
fields.content:
Do you have a manual thermostat? Click here.

Programmable thermostats are probably the most underappreciated appliance around. A programmable thermostat could save you hundreds of dollars while making your home effortlessly comfortable. Unfortunately, all those buttons and setting have intimidated people for years.

If you've been intimidated in the past by your programmable thermostat, don't despair. Having a better home is easier than you think, and it's all just a few clicks away.

Make Your Savings Plan

The ideal time to setback your thermostat is when your home is empty or when you're asleep. Think about when you typically go to bed, leave in the morning, and come home at night. Set your thermostat to lower your heat or air-conditioning while you're asleep or at work, and turn the heat back up by the time you wake up or get home. During the winter, rolling back your thermostat from 72° to 60° for eight hours a day will save you 12% on your heating bill.Department of Energy, Energy Savers, Thermostats and Control Systems You can achieve similar savings in the summer by raising your thermostat in the summer.

Common Thermostat Myths

  • "If I set my thermostat to 80°, my house will get hotter, faster."
    Your heating and cooling system only has two modes: on and off. The rate at which it heats or cools your home is unaffected by the temperature setting. By setting your thermostat higher, you’re just ensuring that your heater will be on for longer than you need and your house will be hotter or colder than you want. Set your thermostat to the temperature you desire.
  • "Turning my thermostat down doesn’t really save energy! My HVAC system will just have to work harder when I get back."
    Using your thermostat to turn your heat or air conditioner down will save energy. Consider the following example:
    Let’s say you want your home to be 72° degrees in the winter. You leave your house at 8am and return at 6pm. If you have a programmable thermostat set to turn the heat off, you will use absolutely no energy during that 10-hour period. If you leave your thermostat at 72°, your heat will continually switch on and off, heating an empty house for 10 hours.
  • "My pipes will freeze!"
    If your pipes are not well insulated inside your home, and the outside air temperature is below 20°, you should consider keeping your thermostat above 55°.Severe Weather Readiness Weather.com. n.d. 7 Apr 2010 This setback still allows room for significant savings. However, a much more effective way to prevent your pipes from freezing and bursting is to insulate exposed pipes.

{% action_form %}
fields.teaser: Do you want a comfortable home that requires no effort or planning? Say a big hello to your programmable thermostat.

fields.name: Dial down your thermostat by two degrees
fields.content:
Stop me if you've heard this one before:

What's the difference between a room that's 72° and a room that's 74°? One happy homeowner who's saving on her energy bills!

You probably won't feel a difference in a room that's two degrees warmer or cooler. But those two degrees can make a world of difference in energy bills. In fact, that savvy homeowner who changed her thermostat is saving as much as $125 every year.Vandenbergh, Michael P. et al. "Individual Carbon Emissions: The Low-Hanging Fruit." UCLA Law Review 1701 (2008): 1744

Would you like to be $125 richer? Raise your thermostat two degrees in the summer and lower it two degrees in the winter!

Step 1: Experiment to find a comfortable setting

While two degrees will save you real cash, you'll save even more if your setback is a bit higher or lower. Find a setting that's comfortable for you and start saving right now.

Step 2: Enact your reduced settings

Just thinking about it doesn't save energy. Do some stretches, warm up your fingers, and go over to your thermostat. With a few pushes of a button, you too can be an energy saving star.

{% action_form %}
fields.teaser: With a few pushes of a button, you too can be an energy-saving star.

fields.name: Seal off vents in unoccupied rooms
fields.content:
Is your house working overtime to heat and cool empty rooms? Take it off the clock with vent covers. Vent covers allow you to prevent unnecessary heating and cooling in hobby rooms, guest rooms, and other occasional-use spaces.

Stick to it

Magnetic vent covers stay in place, but are also easy to remove. They can also be easily cut to size and painted to match your rooms decor.

{% action_form %}
fields.teaser: Stop heating and cooling empty rooms.

fields.name: Change your air conditioning and heater filters every three months
fields.content:
Clean filters help your system run efficiently and last longer. Old filters also contribute to allergies and poor indoor air quality.

Get in the habit of changing your filter regularly. The first day of a new season is the perfect time to replace your filter.

{% action_form %}
fields.teaser: New filters trap dust and other gross stuff, while reducing the operating cost of your heating and cooling system.

fields.name: Use ceiling fans in the summer
fields.content:
Fans not only look nice, but give your room the feel of an island resort. Close your eyes and imagine that cool breeze is from a tropical beach. Best of all, this vacation vibe is also blowing energy savings into your home. Now if only someone would invent an energy-saving Mai Tai.

Step 1: Turn your fan on

Ah, that's better.

Step 2: Raise your thermostat

If you have a fan installed properly, you can raise your thermostat by four degrees and not feel any hotter.Novak, Sara. "Use Fans, Turn the Thermostat Up 4 Degrees." Planet Green. 2 Aug 2009. 25 Jan 2010. Consistently keeping your thermostat four degrees higher in the summer will save you around 12% on your summer cooling bill."3 percent to 5 percent more energy is used for each degree the furnace is set above 68 degrees and for each degree the air conditioner is set below 78 degrees," "Energy Saving Tips. PG&E. n.d. 25 Jan 2010.

{% action_form %}
fields.teaser: Get some wind power in your home.

fields.name: Eliminate "always-on" lights
fields.content:
"Always-on" energy hogs are often found around porches, hallways, and bathrooms. By linking them to a timer or motion sensor, they'll only be on when you need them. You also won't have to worry about remembering to turn them off in the morning.

Put energy hogs on a diet

Timers and motion sensors are available at many hardware stores. Motion sensors usually plug into a single outlet and contain a light. Timers also plug into a single outlet, and then connect to a light you already own. Expect to spend $5-$10 per light.

{% action_form %}
fields.teaser: These gluttonous lights give you a few minutes of useful light, but gulp hours of energy every day.

fields.name: Keep the fireplace damper closed
fields.content:
Your fireplace is supposed to keep you warm, but leaky fireplaces make your house colder by drawing warm air up the flue. Close that damper ASAP!

{% action_form %}
fields.teaser: Open dampers are like open windows in the middle of winter!

fields.name: Install a low-flow shower head
fields.content:
In 1996, Seinfeld showed Kramer's struggle with the shortcomings of a low-flow shower head. Now that we're well into the 21st century, it's time to shake off old fears and embrace the new advances in low-flow shower technology.

Newer models deliver the water pressure you want, without the waste. Trust us: even if Kramer didn't use a low-flow shower head, the Jetsons definitely have one in their home.

Step 1: Buy a low-flow shower head

You can find them at any local home improvement store. Starting in 2010, these high efficiency shower heads will carry the EPA WaterSense logo, making them easy to identify. Low-flow shower heads have a flow rate of less than 2.0 gpm, but most homes only need a 1.5 gpm shower head. The flow rate should be listed on the box. Every shower you take will use 25% less water and energy if you opt for a 1.5gpm shower head over a 2.0 gpm model.

Step 2: Install the shower head

You can easily do the installation yourself. For step-by-step instructions, refer to this article or watch the video below.

{% action_form %}

Frequently Asked Questions

How do I know if my current shower head is low-flow?
The only way to know for sure is to put a pre-measured bucket under the shower head and turn it on. Measure how much water is left in the bucket after a minute. If you have a low-flow shower head, there should be no more than two gallons of water in the bucket after a minute. In reality, most homes do not come with low-flow shower heads installed. Even if your shower head is relatively new, it's flow rate is likely around 2.5gpm. By switching to a 1.5gpm shower head, you would save around $350 over the shower head's lifetime in averted water and energy costs. You'll save nearly twice that if you have an electric-powered water heater!"Residential Product Guides: Shower Heads." Flex Your Power. n.d. 30 March 2010.
fields.teaser: The energy you save by switching one shower head will power your television for over a year.Installing two low-flow shower heads will save the average household 300 kWh per year: WaterSense® Draft Specification for Showerheads Supporting Statement, p. 5A 32" LCD television on for 3 hours, every day uses 139.2 kWh of electricity a year: Bluejay, Michael. "How much electricity does my stuff use?" n.d. 5 March 2010. Seriously.

fields.name: Use ceiling fans in the winter
fields.content:
Using a fan in the middle of winter? Surely you jest.

No, we're as serious as a lower energy bill. Your fan can be a windfall for energy savings all year long. In the summer, your fan cools you down by circulating air and creating a breeze. But in the winter, your fan can push warm air down from your ceiling.

Step 1: Reverse the direction of your fan

Pull out the step ladder and get up close and personal with you fan. You'll quickly find the switch that controls the direction of the fan.

After switching, the blades should rotate in a clockwise direction. You can check this by watching the blades. The blades should spin with the downward turned side going forward.

Step 2: Lower your thermostat

Once you put the ladder away, scope out how the room feels. Warmer? Pretty cool, right?

Okay, wipe that smirk off your face. It's not time to rest on your laurels yet. Turning the fan on only saves you money if you also lower your heat. You should be able to lower your thermostat enough to still feel comfortable while saving around 10% on your heating bills.Underwood, Kristin. "Turn Back Your Clock and Fan This Halloween for Better Energy Savings." Treehugger.com. 28 Oct 2009. 3 March 2010. That's like finding over $60 on the switch of your fan!"Where Does My Money Go?" ENERGY STAR. n.d. 2 Apr 2010.

{% action_form %}
fields.teaser: There's hot air stuck at the top of your ceiling! Use your ceiling fan to put it to good use.

fields.name: Install a low-flow sink aerator
fields.content:
Sink aerators — small pieces that attach to your sinks — are widely available and very inexpensive. For the bathroom, look for an aerator with a flow rate of between 0.5 to 1 gallon per minute. You can also install aerators in your kitchen, but kitchen sinks need a higher flow rate.

But how do I do it?

It's easy!

{% action_form %}
fields.teaser: If every household in the United States installed low-flow faucet accessories, we could save about $600 million in annual energy costs from heating water."WaterSense Labeled Sink Faucets and Accessories." EPA. 25 Feb 2010. 2 March 2010.

fields.name: Replace your incandescent light bulbs with CFLs
fields.content:
You've probably heard it all before, but let's just take a moment to review how awesome compact fluorescent light bulbs (CFLs) are:

  • CFLs are four times more efficient than outdated incandescent light bulbs.ToolBase Services, Compact Fluorescent Lighting
  • The average home has 45 light bulbs. Switching all of these bulbs will save you over $1,300 over the bulbs' lifetimes.Dakss, Brian. "'Green' Light Bulb Buying Guide." CBS News. 22 June 2007. 5 March 2010.ENERGY STAR, "Compact Fluorescent Light Bulbs for Consumers." n.d. 5 March 2010.
  • If every household in the United States installed just one CFL, we would prevent greenhouse gas emissions equivalent to those of more than 800,000 cars annually"Frequently Asked Questions: Information on Compact Fluorescent Light Bulbs (CFLs) and Mercury." Energy Star. July 2008..
  • CFLs last 10 times longer, which means fewer trips to the hardware store and fewer arguments over why there's still a blown out bulb in the kitchen.

There you have it. Install CFLs for a happier, wealthier home.

{% action_form %}

What's the deal with mercury in CFLs?


The rumors are true: CFLs contain a small amount of mercury. Really small — many CFLs now contain less than 1 milligram of mercury.Ibid. To put that in perspective, the average aspirin tablet weighs 325 milligrams. The mercury in these new CFLs weighs as much as 1/325 of an aspirin tablet. Old thermometers, on the other hand, contain around 500 milligrams of mercuryIbid.

Because they do contain a small amount of mercury, CFLs should be recycled at the end of their lives. Visit Earth911 to find a recycling center near you.

No mercury is released when the bulbs are in tact. If you do break a bulb, it's okay. Open a window and leave the room for 15 minutes. When you come back, use tape to pick up any shards of glass, and vacuum the area thoroughly. For more information about CFL disposal, visit the Energy Star information page.

More CFLs = less mercury


Say what? It's true. The adoption of CFLs will actually reduce the amount of mercury released into our environment. Since CFLs are so much more efficient, they require much less energy than incandescent bulbs to produce the same amount of light. That means we can significantly reduce our demand for coal, the most common source of electricity in the U.S. Burning coal is a dirty business. It releases all sorts of nasty chemicals, including a lot of mercury. When you compare their life cycle impacts, CFLs leave incadescents behind in a cloud of smog:

Ibid.
fields.teaser: Compact fluorescent light bulbs (CFLs) are awesome in so many ways. Find out how they'll help you save a bundle in no time.

fields.name: Caulk around your windows
fields.content:
Caulk is like the icing on a cupcake. A cupcake is pretty good on its own, but the icing makes it shine.

Like icing, caulk comes in a tube and costs very little — about $8 a tube. Caulk can be used to seal gaps that are up to 1/4" wide. By adding appropriate air sealing and insulation, the typical home can reduce its total energy bill by 10%."Methodology for Estimated Energy Savings from Cost-Effective Air Sealing and Insulating." Energy Star. n.d. 28 Apr 2010 In fact, adding caulk is one of the most cost-effective energy improvement projects. The best things are always the simplest.

WARNING: No matter how smooth and wonderful your caulking job looks, do not eat caulk. Cupcakes are much more delicious.

Step 1: Select you caulk

Chocolate, vanilla, or rubber, there's the right type of filling for every occasion. Make sure you select a caulk that is designed to seal dissimilar materials. Staff at your local hardware store will be able to assist you in picking the right type of caulk for the job, but butyl rubber caulk is a good choice for most jobs."Energy Savers: Caulking." U.S. Department of Energy. 24 Feb 2009. 5 March 2010.

Step 2: Keep on caulking

This homeowner is applying caulk on the exterior of the house, but adding caulk inside your home is a smart idea too. Common problem areas inside your home include:
  • Where the glass meets your window frame
  • In the joints of molding, doors, and windows
  • Where your window and door frames meet your wall
To perfect your caulking form, try:
  • Holding the gun at a 45º angle, so the caulk is forced into cracks as it comes out.
  • Caulking continually, without multiple stops and starts.
  • Making sure the caulk sticks to both sides of a gap.

{% action_form %}
fields.teaser: Your window may be good at looking pretty, but it also has a job to do: keeping you comfortable. Help it stop drafts and save energy with a fresh coat of caulk.

fields.name: Insulate your windows
fields.content:
Leaky windows are the worst. Recently, we read about a guy who was so frustrated by his leaky windows that he moved to a windowless, underground lair.

Okay...by "guy" we mean "supervillain." And by "read" we mean "saw it on a cartoon." Same thing, right?

The point is that leaky windows can drive you bonkers. You can literally feel money leaving your house through leaks. And the uncomfortable drafts seem like they belong in Little House on the Prairie, not your modern home.

Fortunately, you don't have to go through the hassle and expense of building an underground lair to escape drafts. It's easy to insulate your windows. Here's how:

Step One: Buy an insulation kit

Window insulation kits contain a special plastic sheet and double-sided tape. The sheet traps air between the sheet and glass, creating an insulating barrier. Kits — like those from 3M and Ace — are easy to install and generally cost less than $4 per window.

Step 2: Put it on up

With just some scissors and a few minutes, you can stop uncomfortable drafts. This guy successfully insulates his windows with his eyes covered:

{% action_form %}
fields.teaser: Your windows are costing you a pretty penny every winter. Heat loss from your windows accounts for 10-25% of your winter heating bill."Energy Saver Tips: Windows." Energy Savers. Department of Energy. 22 Jan 2009. 25 Jan 2010. Stop leaks in their tracks with a window insulation kit.

fields.name: Replace your windows
fields.content:
Replacing your windows is an expensive upgrade with a longer payback period, so it probably shouldn't be first on your list. However, if you've already made other improvements, new windows can enhance your home's appearance and performance.

High performance, low bills

Look for "high performance" windows, which absorb/reflect light better than conventional glass. In cold parts of the country, for example, low-e windows are a good choice. They readily absorb heat and reflect it back into the room. In warm areas, spectrally selective glass reduces heat gain while allowing light to pass through."Energy Savers Tips: Windows." Department of Energy. 22 Jan 2009. 3 March 2010.

A contractor will be able to tailor recommendations to your home's needs.

{% action_form %}
fields.teaser: Hello, sunshine. Good bye, drafts.

fields.name: Set your computer to sleep automatically
fields.content:
Is your computer tired? That's no surprise — it's using an awful lot of energy. It's worth putting your computer to sleep whenever you step away from it. By activating sleep mode, you can save $25-$75 per computer annually."Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs)." ENERGY STAR. n.d. 27 Jan 2010. By putting your computer to sleep, you won't be decreasing its lifespan, just your energy bills. And remember, "screen savers" don't save any energy.

Seize the power

It's easy to customize your power management preferences. Set your computer to enter standby or hibernate mode after 30 to 60 minutes of inactivity. Have the monitor turn off after 20 minutes of inactivity.
  • For Windows Users: Start -> Control Panel -> Performance and Maintenance -> Power Options
  • For Mac Users: Applications -> System Preferences -> Energy Saver

fields.name: Retire your second refrigerator
fields.content:
Have you bought a new refrigerator recently? Awesome! You're already seeing the savings of a new fridge and that old, icky, inefficient refrigerator is long gone! Or is it?

If your old refrigerator is still loafing around your home like an annoying houseguest, you're not alone. Around a quarter of American homes now have second refrigerators."Refrigerator Market Profile 2009." U.S. Dept of Energy. Dec 2009, p. 3 That number has more than doubled since 1984.Ibid. p. 9

Hot savings

Keeping all these second refrigerators on the grid sucks a huge amount of energy. The easiest way to get back your savings is to unplug that second refrigerator and send it to be recycled. But sometimes even a super energy saver like you needs to chill a bunch of sodas ASAP. If you need a second refrigerator for holidays or other parties, and keep the refrigerator turned off most of the year. You'll be able to use your refrigerator when you need it, and save when you don't.

Dec 2009, p. 13 By keeping your second refrigerators on, you're not only undoing any energy savings of buying more efficient models, but adding to your monthly energy bill.

fields.name: Save money with a manual thermostat
fields.content:
Do you have a programmable thermostat? Click here.

As you rush out the door in the morning, setting back your thermostat is probably the last thing on your mind. But did you know that taking just a few seconds every morning could save you hundreds of dollars a year? It's true! Your thermostat has the potential to be an enormous energy saver.

But how can you develop this money-saving habit? Here are some tips:

  • Put one person in your family in charge of setting the thermostat every day before you leave. This is a great job for elementary-aged children. Just like turning off lights, setting the thermostat teaches the importance of saving energy to the next generation.
  • Always set your thermostat after doing the same activity. Do you make coffee every morning? Set your thermostat after you finish your cup of joe. By making it part of your routine, your much more likely to remember to turn it back.
